rows.title: Module 2: Talking about Feelings

introduction.eng:
"**Welcome to Module 2: Talking about feelings! ** 

The main goal is for parents to learn  and  practice  talking  about  their  own  feelings  and  their  child's  feelings.

Parents will also learn: 
1️⃣the  importance  of  accepting,  naming,  and  recognizing  the  different  emotions  their  child  is  feeling
2️⃣ ways  and  skills  that  can  help  with  this."

rows.title: What is Safeguarding?

introduction.eng:
It is important to know the following guidelines for handling disclosures of abuse, neglect, and violence from participants:

1️⃣ **Understand abuse, neglect and exploitation.**

❗ **Abuse** refers to a deliberate act of maltreatment that can damage a boy or girl’s security, wellbeing, dignity and development. Abuse includes all forms of physical, sexual, psychological and emotional maltreatment. (Save the Children definition)

❗ **Violence** against girls and boys is defined as forms of physical or mental violence, damage and abuse, neglect or neglectful treatment or maltreatment or exploitation, including sexual abuse. (Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights, 1990,
Article 19)

❗ **Child exploitation** refers to using girls and boys for economic or sexual benefit, gratification or profit, often resulting in unjust, cruel and harmful treatment of the girl or boy. (Save the Children definition)

2️⃣ **Know your organisation’s child safeguarding policies and referral procedures.**

📖 All organisations should have or develop child rights safeguarding policies and referral procedures, including details on how to respond appropriately when a caregiver, other adults, girl or boy discloses abuse. 

📝 You should have accurate knowledge of all protocols and response plans. These will tell you what to do within your organisation if a caregiver or girl or boy reports abuse (e.g. who to report to, internal resources for supporting the girl or boy), as well as how to engage outside resources (e.g. local referral pathways, when to engage with authorities). 

🔑 It is your responsibility to act regardless of whether you are responding to disclosures of past and/or present abuse. However, you are not responsible for resolving the situation on your own. It is important that you discuss the situation with your supervisor to agree on what steps to take next.

3️⃣ **Ensure parents know that you are someone who can help.**

🌷Parents participating in your sessions need to know that they can come to you for help, regardless of when the abuse occurred. 

👂You should make sure that they know that they can trust you and that you will listen and support them without judgement or any further harm.

rows.title: What should I do during the disclosure of abuse, neglect, or exploitation?

title.eng: What should I do during the disclosure of abuse, neglect, or exploitation?

introduction.eng:
**During disclosure:**

💚 Provide a safe environment in which the participant can share their story.

👂 Listen carefully to the participant and take notes: what/when/where/who.

❗ Determine if the participant is in immediate danger and what help is available.

💙 Make sure that the participant feels that you believe him/her.

🌷 Let them know they have done the right thing by sharing their story with you.

✨ Be supportive and free of judgement in your responses – avoid blaming at all times!

➡️ Let the participant know that you will share what he/she told you with your supervisor to find a way to support and protect him/her.

📝 Explain what you are going to do next.

 ✅ Notify @global.supervisor_name

❗Remember that it is not your obligation to solve the situation, but you must report it to your supervisors for follow-up. Don't try to solve it alone.

rows.title: What can I do after a participant discloses abuse, neglect or exploitation?

title.eng: What can I do after a participant discloses abuse, neglect or exploitation?

introduction.eng:
**After disclosure:**

❌ Avoid engaging with the alleged abuser – that may make things worse and make next steps difficult. It could also jeopardise future legal proceedings.

🌷 You are not alone. Get help from your supervisor to agree on the next steps.

rows.introduction:

rows.title: How should I report abuse?

introduction.eng:
✅ Follow your organisation’s protocol.

📝 If your organisation needs assistance in developing or improving its policies and procedures, please refer to the following resources:

**Mexican resources**
1️⃣ [National Inter-institutional Coordination Protocol for the Protection of Girls, Boys and Adolescent Victims of Violence](https://www.gob.mx/sipinna/documentos/protocolo-nacional-de-coordinacion-interinstitucional-para-la-proteccion-de-ninas-ninos-y-adolescentes-victimas-de-violencia) 

2️⃣ [National System for the Protection of Girls, Boys, and Adolescents](https://www.gob.mx/sipinna)

3️⃣ [National Human Rights Commission of Mexico](https://www.cndh.org.mx/pagina/tematicas-y-talleres) 

4️⃣[Inter-ministerial Commission to prevent, punish and eradicate crimes related to trafficking in persons.](https://www.gob.mx/segob/acciones-y-programas/comision-intersecretarial-para-prevenir-sancionar-y-erradicar-los-delitos-en-materia-de-trata-de-personas)

**International resources**
1️⃣ [World Health Organization Guidelines Responding to Girls, Boys, and Adolescents who have Been Sexually Abused](https://iris.paho.org/handle/10665.2/52043) 

2️⃣ [Keeping Girls and Boys Safe](https://www.keepingchildrensafe.global/)

3️⃣ [Caring for Child Survivors of Sexual Abuse](https://www.unicef.org/documents/caring-child-survivors-sexual-abuse) 

4️⃣ [Strengthening Linkages between Clinical and Social Services for Girls, Boys, and Adolescents who have Experienced Sexual Violence: A Companion Guide](https://www.togetherforgirls.org/en/resources/strengthening-linkages-between-clinical-and-social-community-services-for-children-and-adolescents-who-have-experienced-sexual-violence-a-companion-guide) 

5️⃣ [Together for Girls: Every Hour Matters](https://www.togetherforgirls.org/en/campaigns/every-hour-matters)

rows.title: After Onboarding Session

introduction.eng: This chat session should happen on the same day or day after you complete the in-person onboarding session. As the first chat session, it offers a chance for parents to introduce themselves to the group.

section_title_1.eng: Add Ground Rules, previously agreed, to the WhatsApp Group Description

section_text_1.eng:
Remember to add the ground rules to the WhatsApp Group Description. 

​​To add the ground rules to the Group Description, copy the following ground rules or use the ones agreed during the onboarding session: 

“To make this a a comfortable, empathetic and safe space for everyone, here are some ground rules:
 
✅ What is said in the group stays in the group, both in person and online You need to know that this group is private.
✅ Accept each other. Everyone is different and has different experiences.
✅ Share only what you feel comfortable sharing. Avoid topics unrelated to the content of the workshop, advertisements or sales. 
✅Respect each other by paying attention and taking turns to share and listen.
✅The conversation in the WhatsApp group will focus solely on the parenting of children.
✅ Feel free to ask questions! 
✅ Respect privacy of personal pictures and videos that are sent to the chat group. 
✅ I AM only here as an observer. I will not respond to questions about your parenting habits in this group or personally. However, if there is a message that will benefit the entire group, then I will share a general message here.”
✅Connect and participate in the interaction schedule with the facilitator. The schedule to interact in this chat is:[Enter schedule]


Open the WhatsApp group chat. 

Tap the group name. 

Tap the existing description, or tap Add Group Description. 
Paste the ground rules. 

Tap Save.

message_text_1.eng:
😃 Hi there! Welcome to our @global.programme_name WhatsApp Group! 

Today, we are introducing ourselves and our goals for the programme! ⭐ 

My name is [INSERT NAME], and my goal is to learn more about how to help my girl go to bed by 8 every night.⏰🌙 

Please share your name and your goal for @global.programme_name using text or audio message.

message_guidance_1.eng:
Remember to fill in your name where it says [INSERT NAME] before sending your message. 

Allow some time for parents to share. Try to praise each response.

For example, you can say, “Thanks for the response, [Insert Name]!” or “Great goal, [Insert Name]”! You can also use simple emojis like 👍or 🙂

message_title_2.eng: Message 2: Setting time to chat

message_text_2.eng:
This week, we will catch up at [INSERT TIME] on [INSERT DAY] to chat about our @global.programme_name journey. 

👋Please join to share how things are going. Every little step matters. Share what works when you practise, reflections about the topic, any challenges you experience, or just say hi! 😊

⏰Does this time and day work for everyone?

message_guidance_2.eng: Add the time and day of the week before sending the message.

message_text_3.eng:
😃Thank you so much for being part of our WhatsApp chat group! 

As your home practice, try to spend at least 5 minutes of one-on-one time with your child each day. 

We can share how it goes during our next chat session. 

👋See you later.

rows.title: Week 1 Chat Session: Thoughts, Feelings, and Actions

title.eng: Week 1 Chat Session: Thoughts, Feelings, and Actions

introduction.eng:
This chat session will help parents understand the connection between thoughts, feelings, and actions. 
The goal is for caregivers to identify how emotions, feelings, and actions impact their and their girls’, boys’, and teen’s well-being.

message_text_1.eng:
Hello, everyone! 😃
Welcome to our second chat session! 

Let’s chat about how your home activities are going with your child. Please share what went well or if you found anything difficult.

message_guidance_1.eng: Acknowledge the experiences parents share with an appropriate emoji or with a response from the common challenges.

message_title_2.eng: Message 2: Feelings

message_text_2.eng:
Thank you for sharing. 

Just like we take care of our bodies, it's important to take care of our minds as well. As caregivers, it’s important that we learn what mental well-being is and how to promote it not just for your girls, boys and teens, but yourself too! 

Today, we're discussing some of the building blocks of well-being: thoughts, feelings, and actions.

Let's start by sharing how we're feeling today. Are you feeling happy, sad, angry, scared, stressed, confused?... I'll begin!

message_guidance_2.eng: Allow time for caregivers to share how they are feeling. You should also share how you are feeling. For example, “I’m feeling a little tired today, and at the same time very excited for our session together!”

message_text_3.eng:
Thank you all for sharing your honest responses! 🎉

Great! You already know the first important step in taking care of our minds - identify and name our feelings! 

Feelings are like messages that tell us or warn us about how we are doing inside. 
They can be powerful and sometimes influence our thoughts. Similarly, our thoughts can affect how we feel!

When we’re happy, our thoughts are often pleasant too. But when we are sad or angry, our thoughts can also be unpleasant. 

Now, take a moment and think about the thoughts that go along with the feelings you mentioned earlier in the chat. Please share an example in the chat.

message_guidance_3.eng:
Allow parents to respond. You can reply to the parents with an emoji ⭐ or use ACCEPT, to say  “That is a good example! I am sure a lot of us have felt that way”.

If needed, you can provide the following example: “I’ll share an example. I was feeling happy today, and so I thought about spending some time with my son.”

message_text_4.eng:
These are great connections! You’re already learning how thoughts and feelings work together. Now, let’s talk about our actions. 

Actions are the behaviours we take based on our thoughts and feelings. For example, if you feel happy and relaxed while spending time with your girls, boys, and teens, you are more likely to do fun activities together or to respond calmly. On the other hand, if you are feeling stressed or overwhelmed, you might get angry or irritated with your girls, boys, or teens. 

We talked about our feelings and the thoughts that come with them that may affect our actions. Now, in the chat, let’s share how these feelings and thoughts affected your actions today.

message_guidance_4.eng:
Allow parents to respond. You can reply to the parents with an emoji ⭐ or words of encouragement. 

If needed, you can share:“I’ll share an example. One thought I’ve had recently is, when I think about my son playing, I feel happy. When I saw him later that day, I gave him an extra long hug :)”

message_text_5.eng:
Great job! You’ve learned one way in which thoughts, feelings, and actions are connected. 

How we feel and act is affected by what we think. Similarly, how we think and act also affects our feelings. 

Think of it like a triangle: 

        Thoughts
       /               \
Actions  –  Feelings

This week, try noticing this connection in your life or your girls, boys and teen’s. Type in the chat, record a voice note, or write down: 

1) A thought  that popped into your head or a situation that happened
2) How it made you feel
3) How the thought affected your actions

Thank you for participating in this chat session!

message_guidance_5.eng: Allow parents to respond. You can reply to the parents with an emoji ⭐ or words of encouragement.

This week, try noticing this connection in your life or your girls, boys and teen’s. Type in the chat, record a voice note, or write down: 

1) A thought  that popped into your head or a situation that happened
2) How it made you feel
3) How the thought affected your actions

Thank you for participating in this chat session!
rows.message_guidance_5: Allow parents to respond. You can reply to the parents with an emoji ⭐ or words of encouragement.
rows.message_guidance_4:
Allow parents to respond. You can reply to the parents with an emoji ⭐ or words of encouragement. 

If needed, you can share:“I’ll share an example. One thought I’ve had recently is, when I think about my son playing, I feel happy. When I saw him later that day, I gave him an extra long hug :)”

rows.title: Week 2: Self-Talk

introduction.eng:
In this chat, caregivers will learn how the way they talk to themselves can change how they feel. 

They will also practise identifying unkind self-talk and replacing it with kind self-talk.

message_text_1.eng:
Hello, everyone! 😃
Welcome to our third chat session! 

Let’s begin our session by checking how your @global.programme_name home activities are going. 
Did you find anything difficult or want to share anything that went well?

message_guidance_1.eng: Acknowledge the experiences caregivers share with an appropriate emoji or with a response to the common challenges.

message_title_2.eng: Message 2: Understanding Self-Talk

message_text_2.eng:
Thank you all for sharing your honest responses! 🎉

💡 Today, we are going to practise talking kindly to ourselves. 

Last chat session, we learnt that our thoughts affect our feelings and actions. Today, we will practise talking kindly to ourselves, so we can influence our feelings and actions. 

But when we are stressed or overwhelmed, we often say unkind things to ourselves. 

Can anyone share an example of an unkind thing you might say to yourself during the day?

message_guidance_2.eng: Allow parents to respond. You can reply to the parents with an emoji ⭐ or use ACCEPT, like “That is a good example! I am sure a lot of us have felt that way”.

message_text_3.eng:
Thanks for sharing that example! 

1️⃣ You have already taken the first step in talking kindly to yourself - noticing when you have an unpleasant thought about yourself. 
2️⃣ After noticing an unpleasant thought, ask yourself: 

How can I change this unpleasant thought into a kind thought? 
What would a friend or loved one say if I shared this unkind thought? 

3️⃣ Now, let's keep practising this together. Share in the chat the kind thought that came up for you when you asked yourself these questions.

message_guidance_3.eng:
After caregivers share, offer an example: 
For example: 

**Unkind Self-Talk:** "I was a bad parent today. I yelled at my teen for an honest mistake."

**Kind Self-Talk:** "Today was tough because I've been overwhelmed. I yelled at my teen, knowing it was an honest mistake. Next time, I'll pause before responding, ensuring I'm calm and in control."

message_text_4.eng:
This week, notice 3 times when you have an unkind thought towards yourself. Ask yourself, how you can change this into a kind thought. 

Try and write in the chat the unkind thought and the kind thought you came up with. 

Feel free to share in the chat during the week.

message_title_5.eng: Message 5: Three good things and closing

message_text_5.eng:
To close our session, let’s share our three good things from this week.  

Remember, they can be personal, work-related, or family-related. The more detailed, the better!

See you in the next chat session!

message_guidance_5.eng:
Allow caregivers to respond. You can reply to the parents with an emoji ⭐ or words of encouragement. 

If needed, you can share the examples below, or come up with your own. They can be in your personal life, work life, or something from your family. 

“Here are three good things from me: 

I had a great onboarding session with you all this week!
I made a delicious dinner and enjoyed it with my whole family.
Someone at work gave me a compliment and it made me feel very happy.”

rows.title: Week 3: Character Strengths

introduction.eng: This chat session will help caregivers understand how to identify strengths in themselves. They will learn about the connection between strengths and well-being and practice identifying how to incorporate strengths into their daily lives.

message_text_1.eng:
Hello, everyone! 😃

Welcome to our chat session! 

How are things going with your @global.programme_name home activities? Any challenges you've encountered or successes you'd like to share?

message_guidance_1.eng: Acknowledge the experiences caregivers share with an appropriate emoji or with a response from the common challenges.

message_title_2.eng: Message 2: Reflecting on our strengths

message_text_2.eng:
Thank you all for sharing your honest responses! 🎉

Today we are going to talk about our strengths. 

Our strengths are our positive qualities that help us face challenges, build relationships, and help us grow. Some examples of strengths are kindness, patience, and being appreciative of good things in life. 

By being part of this program, you are showing the strength of love of learning and commitment for you girls’, boy’s and teen wellbeing!  

Think about a time when you were enjoying what you were doing. What made you feel energised? Or, what has made it possible for you to get out of difficult situations?  

Share it in the chat!

message_guidance_2.eng:
Allow parents to respond. You can reply to the parents with an emoji ⭐ or use ACCEPT, like “That is a good example! I am sure a lot of us have felt that way”.

You can share an example to begin the conversation: “I really enjoy talking to different people and facilitating.”

message_text_3.eng:
Thanks for sharing!
You know we all have strengths, and we can also develop them over time. Sometimes, it is hard for us to notice all our positive qualities. 
So, let’s reflect on some of the positive qualities you used during the time you mentioned in the chat. 
Was it that you were creative in solving a problem or showed courage in a difficult situation?

message_guidance_3.eng:
Allow caregivers to respond. You can reply to the parents with an emoji ⭐ or words of encouragement, like “These are great!”

If a parent has difficulty thinking of positive qualities, you can share these words for inspiration and normalise it: 

Wanting to learn new things
Not giving up when things are difficult
Being honest
Feeling excited about life
Caring deeply for someone

message_text_4.eng:
What an amazing group of caregivers we have! 

The more we use our positive qualities, the stronger they become. For example, the more we practise thinking of three good things in our life, the more appreciative we become of what we have. 

For practising this skill this week, try to do one activity where you use a strength you identified in the previous message. See how you feel after - the connection between the strengths and well-being is powerful! You can also try this with your child:)  

If you are not sure yet, you can always practise your love of learning by doing a new course in Crianza con Conciencia+. 

Feel free to share in the chat during the week.

message_title_5.eng: Message 5: Three good things and closing

message_text_5.eng:
Next week will be my last chat session with you. But you can keep this WhatsApp group open as a place to continue to support each other!  💚

Is anyone willing to take over as a group admin? 

Please send me a direct message if you are interested. It would be great to get *two volunteers*. 👀

Before we end our session, let’s share our three good things from this week.  

Remember, they can be personal, work-related, or family-related. The more detailed, the better! You can also try this with your girl, boy, teen, or family!

See you in the next chat session!

message_guidance_5.eng:
Allow parents to respond. You can reply to the parents with an emoji ⭐ or use ACCEPT.


You can share an example to begin the conversation: “I have had the absolute pleasure of facilitating this group, and I feel so happy about the community we’ve created!”

rows.title: Week 4: Building Pleasant Emotions

introduction.eng:
This is your final chat session with the group.You should congratulate yourself for taking the parents through the Crianza con Conciencia+ journey and celebrate with them the positive changes in their lives and for their girls, boys, and teens.

In this chat session, you will also help parents understand how they can use pleasant emotions to improve the well-being of themselves and their child or teen. 

You can choose to stay or leave the WhatsApp Group after the program ends.

message_text_1.eng:
Hello, everyone! 😃

Welcome to our final chat session! 

Today, we are wrapping up our conversation about building blocks for mental wellbeing. So far, we’ve identified the relationship between thoughts, feelings, and behaviours, learned about positive self talk, and relying on our character strengths. Great job!

Congratulations on completing the Crianza con Conciencia+ Programme! You can continue to complete the course on the CC+.

✨ Take a moment to think back to the beginning of the programme. You should be so proud of yourself. How was your experience in Crianza con Conciencia+?

message_guidance_1.eng: Allow caregivers to share their experience during the programme. You can give brief words of encouragement like “Wonderful!” or “I am happy to hear that!” or even share celebration emojis like 🎉 or ⭐.

message_title_2.eng: Message 2: Pleasant time with your child

message_text_2.eng:
Thank you for sharing your experiences. 

Now, let’s think back to a time when you and your child did something together that made you feel really good. 

How did it make you feel? Did it make you feel joy, love, pride or inspired? What were you doing? 

If you feel comfortable, you can tell us about it in the chat. We would love to hear your story!

message_guidance_2.eng:
Allow time for caregivers to share stories. If needed, feel free to share an example: 

My teen and I cooked dinner together, and we had such a great time. I felt so joyful doing a fun activity together. He is learning all the best recipes from me:).

message_text_3.eng:
Thank you for sharing! 

We all experience pleasant emotions throughout our lives, but did you know that you can boost your well-being by boosting pleasant emotions and thoughts? This works for you and your child or teen! 

Some ways we have talked about in our chat sessions are: 
Thinking of three good things that happened during the day. 
Remember our chat last time about positive qualities? You and your child could do activities together that brings out the positive qualities in both of you. 
When you feel pleasant emotions and share it with your child, they feel it too! 

When your well-being needs a boost, start by trying these activities. 

Which of these do you think you can continue doing even after the programme has ended?

message_guidance_3.eng: Allow caregivers to respond. You can reply to the parents with an emoji ⭐ or words of encouragement, like “That sounds great!” or “Don’t worry, you can always plan to try it later this week.”

message_title_4.eng: Message 4: Three Good Things and Group Admin

message_text_4.eng:
Thank you for sharing. 🏅

Before we close, let’s share our three good things from this week all together.  

Remember, they can be personal, work-related, or family-related. The more detailed, the better! You can keep this up after I leave the WhatsApp Group.

Although this is my last chat session with you, you are in good hands with your new chat group admin: [INSERT NAMES OF MODERATORS] 💙

message_text_5.eng:
It's been wonderful being part of this amazing parent program with all of you! Saying goodbye makes me a bit sad. 

As I shared with you during the onboarding session, I will now be exiting this WhatsApp Group. 👋

You are the best parents to your girls, boys and teens.  *You can still complete your final Crianza con Conciencia+ lessons if you have not done so yet*. 🌱

We all face difficult situations sometimes, and these final parts of @global.programme_name will help you and your child to get through them well. 

You’ve got this! ⭐You are doing a wonderful job as a caregiver. It has been a pleasure to be on this journey with you!

rows.title: A parent needs support accessing the chatbot, and I'm not sure how to answer their question.

title.eng: A parent needs support accessing the chatbot, and I'm not sure how to answer their question.

introduction.eng: Reach out for support to @global.supervisor_name.

rows.introduction: Reach out for support to @global.supervisor_name.

rows.title: A parent cannot commit to the ground rules.

title.eng: A parent cannot commit to the ground rules.

introduction.eng:
Ground rules make your WhatsApp Support Group a comfortable, empathetic and safe space for everyone. 

If someone forgets the ground rules, send the message below to remind them of their importance gently. 

If necessary, share a group reminder about the importance of maintaining a positive and respectful space. 

If, despite reminders, the parent continues not to follow the rules, notify your supervisor. 

You can remove the parent from the group as the last option, done only when you feel it is necessary. For example, if a member repeatedly (more than twice) shares unrelated content, uses inappropriate language, or disrespects another member. 

If you do remove someone from the group, it should be handled with sensitivity and respect. Make sure you talk privately with the parent, remind the group about ground rules, and notify your supervisor.

message_title_1.eng: Send this reminder message to the group

message_text_1.eng:
Hello ⭐

👀 I'd like to take a moment to remind everyone about the importance of our group's ground rules. 

💚They're here to ensure that all of us feel comfortable sharing and maintain a positive environment. 

🌱It's all about making this group a great place for everyone.

❗Please keep in mind that if the ground rules aren't consistently followed, we might need to consider removing members from the WhatsApp group for the well-being of all.

See you in the next chat session.

message_title_2.eng: Send this reminder message to the parent who broke the  ground rule

message_text_2.eng:
Hello ⭐

👀 Creating a positive environment in our WhatsApp group is important, and that relies on everyone following the ground rules.

🌱 I believe in the strength of our community. 

However, if difficulties continue, I may have to consider removing you from the group. 

Let's work together to maintain a respectful and supportive atmosphere. 

See you in the next chat session.

message_title_3.eng: Send this message to the parent after removing them from the WhatsApp Group

message_text_3.eng:
Hello ⭐

👀 I have noticed despite reminders, the ground rules aren't being followed.

💚You can continue learning from @global.programme_name, but unfortunately I have removed you from the WhatsApp group to maintain a positive environment for everyone.

message_guidance_3.eng:
Notify your supervisor once you remove them. 

You can block the parent if they continue to reach out to you.

message_title_4.eng: Send this message to the group after removing the parent who broke the ground rule

message_text_4.eng:
Hello Everyone ⭐,

👀 We want our group to be positive for everyone, and that means following the rules.

💚 Unfortunately, someone had to be removed because they weren't following the rules despite reminders.

Let's keep things respectful and supportive.

See you in the next chat session!

rows.title: A parent is personally messaging me or calling me with lots of questions on their parenting habits or child’s misbehaviours.

title.eng: A parent is personally messaging me or calling me with lots of questions on their parenting habits or child’s misbehaviours.

introduction.eng:
Parents may see you as someone they can turn to for help beyond school and @global.programme_name, especially when they need advice on their child’s  behaviour. 

Even though you want to help, finding a balance for your well-being is important. 

Share the following message to gently remind the parents about your role in @global.programme_name. 

If the parents continue to persist, notify @global.supervisor_name.

message_title_1.eng: Send This Message to the Parent

message_text_1.eng:
Hi!😃Thank you for your message. 

My role in this activity is limited to only sharing messages in the group. I unfortunately do not have the capacity to respond to each individual message.😔

🔑 If you are comfortable posting your questions in the group, please feel free to do so during our chat sessions! 💡

You can also type MENU in @global.programme_name to get more support about the courses.

rows.title: What if no one participates?

introduction.eng:
Engaging parents in the group chat can sometimes be hard. Some parents may need a nudge to share their experiences, or they might be busy with their schedules. 

Sometimes, caregivers need only one person to participate. 

If your chat goes silent after the prompt, consider sharing these ideas or suggestions:

message_title_1.eng: Directly ask a specific parent to share

message_text_1.eng: [Enter a Parent's Name], we'd love to hear about your week with @global.programme_name. Would you be interested in sharing how it went?

message_guidance_1.eng: Before hitting send, please make sure to tag a specific parent by typing @Parent’s Name

message_title_2.eng: Check if it is a good time for WhatsApp Chat

message_text_2.eng:
Hello Parents, 👋

⏱️I value your time and want to ensure our chat is convenient for everyone. 

⭐Does this time work well for our conversations? 

🔔Is there another time that works for you? 

Your input matters!

rows.title: Only a small group of parents are actively participating in the chat sessions, while other parents are not responding.

title.eng: Only a small group of parents are actively participating in the chat sessions, while other parents are not responding.

introduction.eng:
Getting everyone to join in the chat sessions can be a bit challenging. Some parents might be busy, shy, or just prefer to read about other’s experiences. 

Here are some helpful tips to encourage participation: 

1. Directly ask a question to someone by typing @parent name on WhatsApp. 

2. Share one of the messages below with the entire group. 

3. Consider sending a private message to a parent (see the message below).

message_text_1.eng:
🔔 Quick Reminder:

We all benefit when everyone joins in! Your experiences are important. Share your thoughts, and let's keep this group lively and supportive for everyone. 🌷

message_title_2.eng: Praising active parents

message_text_2.eng:
Big shoutout to those actively participating! 

🌟 Your experiences matter. 

We'd love to hear from you if you haven't shared yet. 

Every parent is important! 💚

message_text_3.eng:
Just a friendly reminder: This group is a safe space for sharing and learning. 💙

We encourage everyone to participate and make this a positive experience for all. 🌱

Let's build a supportive community together! 🌷

message_text_4.eng:
Hi there! 👋 

We've noticed you haven't shared much in the group. 

Is there anything specific you'd like to see or discuss? 

Your input is important to us!

Feel free to share your thoughts. 😊

message_text_5.eng:
If you are not yet comfortable sharing, you can respond with an emoji and a comment if you relate to someone else's experience!

Your comfort is important to us, and we appreciate your participation in a way that feels right for you. 😊

rows.title: I don’t understand how thoughts, feelings, and actions are connected.

title.eng: I don’t understand how thoughts, feelings, and actions are connected.

introduction.eng:
If caregivers need more support, you can share more examples. Try breaking it down into Situation, Thought, Feeling, and Action. 

Remember, the goal is to show how a thought creates or changes a feeling, and the feeling creates or changes an action

message_title_1.eng: Share this message with the parent

message_text_1.eng:
Hi! Sometimes it’s hard to see how our thoughts connect to our feelings. 

It can all begin with a feeling, thought or action and affect the other two:

                Thoughts
               /               \
        Actions  –  Feelings

You can break this relationship down into Situation, Thought, and Feeling, and list each statement next to the label. For example: 

Situation: My child keeps interrupting me when I’m speaking. 

Thought: He is being inconsiderate of me and disrespectful.

Feeling: I’m now annoyed and irritated because I’m trying to finish something. 

Can you think of one situation that happened? What did it make you think? How did you feel?

message_title_2.eng: If you want to share an example:

message_text_2.eng: One thought I’ve had recently is, it’s challenging to calm down when my child is crying. It made me feel overwhelmed and upset.

rows.title: I don’t know what thoughts are affecting my feelings or actions.

title.eng: I don’t know what thoughts are affecting my feelings or actions.

introduction.eng:
Parents may struggle to identify thoughts that are affecting their feelings or actions. This is normal, as this is a new skill for many! 

Sometimes, thoughts and feelings can be very similar to one another, and that is ok. 

The goal is just for them to understand that they are related and how they can impact their and their girl’s, boy’s and teens well-being. 

You can guide the parents by asking the following questions:

message_text_1.eng: It can be difficult to identify thoughts sometimes, particularly when you have an intense feeling.

message_title_2.eng: Message 2:

message_text_2.eng: When you feel this way, what is going through your head?

message_text_3.eng: What was happening around you that made you feel this way? Notice what feelings and thoughts and thoughts come up?

rows.title: Parents began insulting themselves during the chat session

title.eng: Parents began insulting themselves during the chat session

introduction.eng: During our chat, parents might speak unkindly about themselves. If this happens, it's important to correct them gently. While it's okay to share examples of negative self-talk when asked, if it occurs in other parts of the conversation, the facilitator should step in to help guide the discussion positively.

section_text_1.eng:
If a parent is being unkind to themselves, they might already realise it. To help, gently suggest a kinder language. For example

Parent: "I’m an okay parent, even though I often mess up."

Facilitator: "Thank you for sharing. Great job recognizing your strength. Let's re-word this unkind talk. How about:
💚 'I’m an okay parent, even though I’m overwhelmed right now.'
💛 'Even when I don’t have all the answers.'
💙 'It's okay to make mistakes and learn from them.'

You can choose one of these or create a new one. Parents might not be used to positive self-talk so a little encouragement can go a long way!

section_text_2.eng: Remind parents that this space is a supportive community. Encourage parents to share words of encouragement and positive things they say to themselves. This helps create a supportive environment for everyone.

rows.title: Caregivers express intentions of self-harm or harm to their girls, boys, and teens during the session.

title.eng: Caregivers express intentions of self-harm or harm to their girls, boys, and teens during the session.

introduction.eng:
If a parent is showing intention to self-harm or harm to their girls and boys, remember, they may be experiencing an intense emotion. Remember, the best thing you can do is follow safeguarding protocols and refer them to services that can provide the help they need.

Report to your supervisor after sending the following message privately to the parent:

message_text_1.eng:
Dear [INSERT NAME], 

This space is here to support you. If you or someone else is in immediate danger, consider calling La Línea de la Vida at 800 911 2000 or SAPTEL at 55 5259 8121 for assistance.

You can also type @global.trigger_help in @global.programme_name to find more resources for support. 

Your safety and well-being is important to us, and we are here to help. Asking for help is a brave and healthy act

message_guidance_1.eng: Write the name of the parent before sending the message.

rows.title: Parents could not turn negative self-talk into positive self-talk

title.eng: Parents could not turn negative self-talk into positive self-talk

introduction.eng:
At times, parents may find it challenging to transform negative self-talk into positive self-talk during the chat session. If this happens, remember that everyone moves at their own pace. Stay calm and offer support with a different perspective:

1️⃣ Imagine someone you love is going through a similar situation.
2️⃣ Consider what they might need to hear to feel better.
3️⃣ Use the same words you identified and say them to yourself.

We're not aiming for perfection; you're doing your best with what you have. Keep practising these steps, and gradually, the task will become easier.

You can send the message below:

message_text_1.eng:
If you are struggling to say kind or caring words to yourselves, try this: 

1️⃣ Imagine someone you love is going through a similar situation.
2️⃣ Think about what they might need to hear to feel better.
3️⃣ Use those same comforting words and say them to yourself.

Remember, you're not alone, and treating yourself with kindness matters.

rows.title: I can’t identify my strengths.

introduction.eng:
Some caregivers may struggle with identifying strengths. This is a new skill that for some may come naturally, but others may struggle with, especially if they have not had experiences that connect them with their strengths. Encouraging parents to look at the list of strengths provided in message guidance is the best way to help them identify their own. 

Some parents may not want to participate, and that is okay! The most important thing is for parents to understand what strengths are so that they can help their girls, boys  or teen find their strengths

You can share these messages to support them:

message_text_1.eng:
Hi! It can be hard to think of our strengths, but trust me, we all have them. 

Let’s try an exercise together. I am going to share some positive qualities, and I want you to try putting these in order for what is most like you to least like you. 
I’m a good listener.  

I love learning new things

I give helpful advice to others

I am brave

Everyone has strengths!

message_title_2.eng: Send this to caregivers:

message_text_2.eng:
Hi! Even if you don’t know it, you will have positive qualities, including as a parent. 

You are here trying to be better and that show’s love of learning. 

You do what you can to love and care for your child. That’s the strength of love! 

Can you think of something good that happened with you as a caregiver? What positive quality do you think you used?

rows.title: If parents reach out to you after the group has ended.

title.eng: If parents reach out to you after the group has ended.

introduction.eng:
If parents or group admins reach out to you after the group has ended, it means that you have been helpful to them, which is amazing! 

Parents may see you as a source of support outside of @global.programme_name, but it is important to keep things balanced. 

Share this message to guide the parents to other places for support gently.

message_text_1.eng:
Hi!😃Thank you for your message. 

My role with @global.programme_name was limited. I unfortunately will not be further involved with the programme. 

If your WhatsApp Support group is still active, feel free to post your questions in the group. Other parents may be able to support you with helpful suggestions. 💡

You can replay the programme by typing @global.trigger_menu or typing @global.trigger_help if you need assistance for an emergency.

rows.title: Participants share that the programme was not helpful or that they are still struggling

title.eng: Participants share that the programme was not helpful or that they are still struggling

introduction.eng:
Every family is different, and some parents may need more help than others.

Consider sending the message below if a parent is still struggling or needs more support.

message_text_1.eng:
Hello 👋

Thank you for sharing your thoughts about the programme. I’m sorry that you’re facing challenges. Here are a couple of things you can try: 

1️⃣If there’s a lesson that you are finding difficult, remember you can always go back to it by typing @global.trigger_menu. Practice makes perfect! ✨

2️⃣If you feel comfortable, please feel free to chat about the areas you’re finding tough with your peers in the WhatsApp Support Group. Your peers might have some helpful tips 👍

3️⃣If you are facing a severe situation, please type @global.trigger_help to access a list of resources. 

Remember, everyone’s learning journey is unique, and change takes time. But trust me, if you keep practising the skills you’ve learned, you’ll start to see progress. 🏅

rows.title: Parents are feeling concerned, stressed or sad as the programme comes to an end.

title.eng: Parents are feeling concerned, stressed or sad as the programme comes to an end.

introduction.eng:
It is normal for parents to feel sad or emotional when the programme ends, and you leave the group. This means that parents found the chat sessions helpful and enjoyed participating. What a gift you have given them! Congratulations! 

To support them with this transition, consider sending the message below.

message_text_1.eng:
Hello 👋

Thank you for sharing your feelings. 
It’s okay to have fears or feel sad when something you’ve been a part of is ending. 

Remember, 

1️⃣Even though @global.programme_name is ending, your journey can continue. You have gained some ⭐amazing ⭐parenting skills that you can carry with you. 

2️⃣The WhatsApp group can be a source of support well beyond the programme. Keep sharing your successes and struggles in the WhatsApp Group or with your peers. 

3️⃣If you ever want to go back to any lesson, you can type MENU. Practice makes perfect ✨

4️⃣ You can type HELP to look for other resources that are available for you. 

You did great throughout the @global.programme_name journey!

rows.title: Guide for In-Person Onboarding

introduction.eng: The Onboarding Session sets the tone for the entire @global.programme_name programme. It is important to create a welcoming and safe space for the participants to feel at ease and familiarise themselves with the programme.

section_text_1.eng:
- Read the Facilitator Guide on Formando Conciencia+ 

- Practise the onboarding session with a peer or supervisor

section_text_2.eng:
- Download the PowerPoint slide to your laptop 

- Download the videos embedded in the slides to your laptop 

- Go through your PowerPoint slides and videos to make sure everything is working smoothly

rows.title: How to Conduct WhatsApp Group Chat Sessions

title.eng: How to Conduct WhatsApp Group Chat Sessions

introduction.eng:
The @global.programme_name programme includes WhatsApp support Groups with parents with pre-scripted messages that you share from Formando Conciencia+

The aim of this group is to provide parents with extra support during their @global.programme_name journey.

section_text_1.eng:
**Make sure you have done the following before the onboarding session starts:** 

- Save the names and WhatsApp numbers of the parents assigned to you on your phone (if available), so you can easily confirm details during the onboarding session. 

- Create your WhatsApp group (with the temporary group name, icon, and description). The name of each WhatsApp group has the same structure:
“CC+ WhatsApp Support Group”
A name selected by the group 

When you create your temporary group name, you will use "CC+ WhatsApp Support Group” 

You can keep your temporary group name or you can add a name to the temporary group name. For example, “CC+ __HappyFamilies”.

section_text_2.eng:
**Before conducting the chat sessions, make sure you:** 

Create a WhatsApp Group during the onboarding session. 
Identify the ground rules for the WhatsApp Group

**Structure for the chat sessions**: 

Day  1 (immediately after the onboarding session): Welcome, introductions, and reminder of home practice. 

Day 3: Self-talk: WhatsApp Chat session on self-talk and stress

Day 5: Checking in on parents’ experience and closing

**When to send the messages** 

You and your group will decide a time to chat during the onboarding session. 

Each chat session has a reminder message (Message 1) that you should send a few hours before the chat session. 

Send the remaining messages during the scheduled chat time.

section_title_3.eng: Share the messages in the chat session

section_text_3.eng:
Look for the "Chat Sessions" section on the Formando Conciencia+ homepage

Find the specific chat session you want to share and click on it.

Once you're on the content for that session, locate the "Share" icon. It should look like an arrow pointing upward or a box with an arrow, and it's used to share content. Click on the "Share" icon.

Select "WhatsApp" as your sharing option in the menu that appears.

Choose your @global.programme_name Support Group from the list. 

Before you hit the "Send" button, make sure to add or change any necessary information like your name. 

Finally, click the "Send" button to share the content with your @global.programme_name Support Group.

section_title_4.eng: Get Help with WhatsApp Support Group

section_text_4.eng:
If you require help while moderating your WhatsApp Support Group, the chat sessions provide a list of FAQs and potential solutions.

If you need support responding to a challenge shared by the parent during your chat session, see “Common Challenges” on the homepage. 

Follow the same instructions as Sharing Chat Messages to share the solutions to the challenges. 

If you encounter a challenge not covered in the chat session, kindly contact your supervisor for further guidance.It is better to ask and not share wrong information

rows.section_title_4: Get Help with WhatsApp Support Group
rows.section_text_4:
If you require help while moderating your WhatsApp Support Group, the chat sessions provide a list of FAQs and potential solutions.

If you need support responding to a challenge shared by the parent during your chat session, see “Common Challenges” on the homepage. 

Follow the same instructions as Sharing Chat Messages to share the solutions to the challenges. 

If you encounter a challenge not covered in the chat session, kindly contact your supervisor for further guidance.It is better to ask and not share wrong information

rows.title: Overview of the @global.programme_name Programme

introduction.eng:
Welcome to the @global.programme_name Positive Parenting Programme! 

Thank you for your commitment and dedication to supporting girls, boys, teens and families in your community. 
You are a shining star!

section_text_1.eng:
This guide is for YOU!! 
A comprehensive guide to help you deliver @global.programme_name to families around you. 
Steps on how to introduce caregivers to the programme and support them
Specific information on the programme’s content.

section_text_2.eng:
It is important to follow this manual as closely as possible. However, manuals are only a guide to support you after what you have learned in the training workshop. 
What you deliver – the content of the manual – is only 20% of the programme. The rest 80%? It’s all about HOW you facilitate the programme and behave towards the parents.

section_text_3.eng: The core skills of a good facilitator are a mirror for parents to learn how to bring about the change we want to see in parents and the community. These include understanding stages of child development, praising and encouraging parents, using active listening skills, being consistent and compassionate, exploring problems, and finding solutions together.

section_text_4.eng:
Just as we say to the parents, “It is what you do at home that makes the difference,” the same thing applies to you: “It is how you interact with the parents in your group that makes the difference.” 

If you take the time to deliver a session before it begins, you will be more confident. If there is anything that you cannot remember or feel unsure of, contact another facilitator to practise with. 

Access the Facilitator Guide for your group by clicking on the icon above.

rows.title: How to Conduct WhatsApp Support Group Chat Sessions

title.eng: How to Conduct WhatsApp Support Group Chat Sessions

introduction.eng:
The @global.programme_name programme includes WhatsApp support  Groups with parents with pre-scripted messages that you share from Formando Conciencia+

The aim of this group is to provide parents with extra support during their @global.programme_name journey.

section_text_1.eng:
**Make sure you have done the following before the onboarding session starts:** 

- Save the names and WhatsApp numbers of the parents assigned to you on your phone (if available), so you can easily confirm details during the onboarding session. 

- Create your WhatsApp group (with the temporary group name, icon, and description). The name of each WhatsApp group has the same structure:
“CC+ WhatsApp Support Group”
A name selected by the group 

When you create your temporary group name, you will use "CC+ WhatsApp Support Group” 

You can keep your temporary group name or you can add a name to the temporary group name. For example, “CC+ __HappyFamilies”.

section_text_2.eng:
**Before conducting the chat sessions, make sure you:** 

Create a WhatsApp Group during the onboarding session. 
Identify the ground rules for the WhatsApp Group

**Structure for the chat sessions**: 

Day  1 (immediately after the onboarding session): Welcome, introductions, and reminder of home practice. 

Week 1: Thoughts, feelings, and actions

Week 2: Kind self-talk

Week 3: Character strengths

Week 4: Building pleasant emotions

**When to send the messages** 

You and your group will decide a time to chat during the onboarding session. 

Before each chat session, send the reminder message few hours before the chat session. You can set alarms on your phone to remind you when to send messages.

Send the remaining messages during the scheduled chat time.

section_title_3.eng: Share the messages in the chat session

section_text_3.eng:
Look for the "Chat Sessions" section on the Formando Conciencia+ homepage

Find the specific chat session you want to share and click on it.

Once you're on the content for that session, locate the "Share" icon. It should look like an arrow pointing upward or a box with an arrow, and it's used to share content. Click on the "Share" icon.

Select "WhatsApp" as your sharing option in the menu that appears.

Choose your @global.programme_name Support Group from the list. 

Before you hit the "Send" button, make sure to add or change any necessary information like your name. 

Finally, click the "Send" button to share the content with your @global.programme_name Support Group.

section_title_4.eng: Get Help with WhatsApp Support Group

section_text_4.eng:
If you require help while moderating your WhatsApp Support Group, the chat sessions provide a list of FAQs and potential solutions.

If you need support responding to a challenge shared by the parent during your chat session, see “Common Challenges” on the homepage. 

Follow the same instructions as Sharing Chat Messages to share the solutions to the challenges. 

If you encounter a challenge not covered in the chat session, kindly contact your supervisor for further guidance.

rows.title: How to Report on Programme Delivery

title.eng: How to Report on Programme Delivery

introduction.eng:
The Formando Conciencia+ also makes reporting on the delivery of @global.programme_name much easier than paper forms.

After adding each parent’s name to the App, you will be able to report on their participation during in-person and WhatsApp group sessions.

You will also report on your own experience, including the time spent conducting each session and whether you were able to do all the activities in the session. Be honest with the information, we are really interested in knowing your experience

section_text_1.eng:
Select the profile icon from the bottom navigation bar. 

Choose “About you” 

Type your name under “Your name” 

Select your state from the dropdown menu 

Tap Save

section_text_2.eng:
Select the profile icon from the bottom navigation bar. 

Choose “Add Parent”

Enter parent details in the form. To enter the parent’s unique identifier (UID), ask them to text “ID” on @global.programme_name. Copy the 6-digit number into the parent profile.

section_text_3.eng:
If two parents from the same family are participating in the programme, together, you must link their accounts. 

Once you have added the first parent profile, to add a second parent, select “Add Parent”

Enter parent details in the form. To enter the parent’s unique identifier (UID), ask them to text “ID” on @global.programme_name. Copy the 6-digit number into the parent profile. 

Select “Add Co-Parent”

Select the co-parent from available parent user profiles. 

Select “Save”

*Both parent profiles will be updated to note the co-parent.*

section_text_4.eng:
Select the pencil icon from the bottom navigation bar. 

Select whether you are reporting on an in-person or WhatsApp session with your parents. 

Choose which session you are reporting on. 


Complete the report 

⏰Specify the time spent on preparation, travel, and actual session delivery. 

✅Check the activities you completed (in-person) or the number of messages you sent (WhatsApp Group)

🔵Selecting the parents who participated in the session:

For in-person sessions, “participation” is defined as parents who attended the session, in part or whole. 
For the WhatsApp group, “participation” is defined as parents who have sent at least 1 message during the chat session. 

If you do not see a parent’s name, then you need to add that parent to the App (see above).

section_text_5.eng:
Only edit an attendance report if you have made a mistake.

Select the pencil icon from the bottom of the navigation bar. 

Select whether you want to edit an in-person or WhatsApp session. 

Select the session that you want to edit.

Your previous selections will appear. You can now edit your selections and select “Save”

rows.title: Coaching support

introduction.eng:
Once you join the program, you'll be matched with a coach right from the start. 

Your coach will help you prepare for your chat sessions with the caregivers, talk about any problems you had during your sessions, find solutions together, and practise them. 

You will have 4 coaching sessions with other facilitators and your coach. Each coaching session will be 60 minutes long.

section_title_1.eng: How will the coach get in touch with me?

section_text_1.eng: Make sure you're part of a WhatsApp group with other facilitators from your state and your coach. Your coach will share important information with you through this group. Stay connected and keep an eye out for updates from your coach in the WhatsApp group!

section_title_2.eng: When will the coaching session happen?

section_text_2.eng:
Here is the schedule for your coaching session: 

Session 1: After you conduct the in-person onboarding session

Session 2: After first WhatsApp chat session on thoughts, feelings, and actions

Session 3: After second WhatsApp chat session on kind self-talk

Session 4: After third WhatsApp chat session on character strengths

section_text_3.eng:
Before your coaching session: 

Review your WhatsApp chat session with the parents 
Select a challenge or issue from your chat session that they want to receive support from during coaching. A challenge is a specific issue or difficulty the facilitators faced during their chat session.  
Think about what coaching skills you want to improve. For example, you could build a stronger sense of community amongst the caregivers or improve their facilitation skills.

section_text_4.eng:
If you need support and your coaching session is a while from now, you can share your challenge in the WhatsApp group with other facilitators. 

Other facilitators may have faced similar challenges and may be able to support you.

rows.title: How to hand over to Group Admin

title.eng: How to hand over to Group Admin

introduction.eng:
Once 2 volunteers to be group admin are selected, schedule a WhatsApp call with them.

When you’re done with the call, you can send the guidelines as messages to remind them what you discussed.

section_title_1.eng: What to cover in the WhatsApp Call?

section_text_1.eng:
Thank the parents for volunteering to lead the WhatsApp group.  

While engaging with other parents in the group, keep the following in mind:
🔵Greet parents when engaging with them.
🔵Respect what participants share and be aware of different ages, genders, values and circumstances.
🔵Encourage parents to share and respond to each other - and praise them for it.
🔵Remind parents of ground rules when needed.
🔵Model the behaviour you want to see among the parents.

If the parent needs any prompts for discussion, share the following: 

Let us celebrate our successes! What was something positive you experienced when you tried one of the @global.programme_name skills with your child?

Trying out new skills can be hard at first. What was something difficult that you experienced when you tried a @global.programme_name skill with your child at home?
Remind the parent that they are not obligated to respond to messages all times. Participants may send messages at any time during the week. To keep your workload manageable, you can respond to messages once or twice a day, depending on your schedule. 

Ask them if they have any questions. 

Remind the parent that unfortunately, you will no longer be able to participate in the WhatsApp group.

message_title_1.eng: Send this message after your WhatsApp Call

message_text_1.eng:
Hi! Thank you for volunteering to lead the group discussions. 

*While engaging with other parents in the group, keep the following in mind*: 

👋Greet parents when engaging with them.

💛Respect what participants share and be aware of different ages, genders, values and circumstances. 

🏅Encourage parents to share and respond to each other - and praise them for it.

🔔Remind parents of ground rules when needed.

🔑Model the behaviour you want to see among the parents.

message_title_2.eng: When should the group admin respond to messages?

message_text_2.eng:
*When should you respond to messages?*

⏰Participants may send messages at any time during the week. To keep your workload manageable, you can respond to messages once or twice a day, depending on your schedule. 

👍You can also respond to messages with a relevant emoji or short response when you can.

message_guidance_2.eng: Send this message to the group admin volunteers.

rows.title: Chat session prompts for new group admin

title.eng: Chat session prompts for new group admin

introduction.eng: After your call with the new group admin, you can share these prompts to support them with leading the chat sessions.

message_text_1.eng: 🎉Let us celebrate our successes! What was something positive you experienced when you tried one of the @global.programme_name skills with your boy or girl?

message_text_2.eng: 🌱Trying out new skills can be hard at first. What was something *difficult* that you experienced when you tried a @global.programme_name skill with your boy or girl at home?

rows.title: No one volunteered to be group admin

title.eng: No one volunteered to be group admin

introduction.eng:
It may be difficult to find volunteers to become group admin. If no one volunteers to lead the group, you can send the message below to close the group. 

Wait a couple days before closing because someone might still volunteer!

message_text_1.eng:
Thank you for sharing your thoughts 💙

Since we don’t have any volunteers for group admin, I will be closing this WhatsApp Support Group at the end of the Programme. 

Remember, you can still continue your @global.programme_name journey with your family!

rows.title: Spending one-on-one time

introduction.eng:
Parenting can be challenging and many obstacles can get in the way.

Remember, your job isn't to solve their problems but to enable a conversation between parents to support one another. 🔄

Here are some common challenges and possible solutions for spending one-on-one time that we have encountered previously when delivering the programme. 

You can share the following messages as responses during your chat sessions when parents share challenges with this topic.

message_title_1.eng: I didn’t have enough time to spend one-on-one time.

message_text_1.eng: ✨Thank you for sharing. It can be hard to find time, especially when you have work, chores, and other responsibilities to do.🙂 You could try finding a chore to do together.

message_title_2.eng: My child did not want to spend time with me.

message_text_2.eng: ✨Thank you for sharing. It feels sad when your child doesn't want to spend time with you. 🙂Try suggesting a fun activity to do together.

message_title_3.eng: All my child wanted to do was watch T.V. or play with a gadget.

message_text_3.eng:
It can be tough when your teen, girl, or boy seems focused on watching TV or playing with a gadget all the time. ✨ 

To connect with them and understand their interests, try asking them to show you something cool on the gadget. 

It's a simple way to engage with their world and spend time together. 📺

message_title_4.eng: My child did not want one-on-one time to end.

message_text_4.eng:
I understand it can be tough when your child does not want one-on-one time to end.✨

To make things smoother, try being clear about how much time you have together and give a gentle warning when the time is about to end. ⏰

message_title_5.eng: My child wanted to do activities that I could not do.

message_text_5.eng:
I can imagine it's challenging when your child wants to do activities that you find difficult. ✨

A simple solution is to ask your child if you can join in by watching.  

This way, you're still involved and supportive, even if you can't participate directly. 🤝

rows.title: Praising your child

introduction.eng:
It is normal for caregivers to feel uncomfortable or have challenges when praising their boys, girls, and teens. They may at first think that praise will either inflate their girls, boys, or teens or is not part of what they were taught. 

It is important to remember that there are many different ways to praise boys, girls, and teens. @global.programme_name focuses mainly on praise as a method to reinforce positive behaviour. We praise the behaviour more than just the child! With practice it will become easier and more comfortable.

Here are some common challenges and possible solutions for praising your child. 

You can share the following messages as responses during your weekly chat when parents share challenges with this topic.

message_title_1.eng: I forgot to praise my child.

message_text_1.eng:
💚It can be difficult to juggle all the different things we need to do. 

🌱Next time you spend one-on-one time, try and think of one thing you can praise them for. 

☀️You can even say, “Thank you for spending time with me!”

message_title_2.eng: I felt embarrassed or weird when praising my child.

message_text_2.eng:
⭐It’s normal to feel uneasy about doing new things.

🌷This is especially true of praise when we are not used to hearing it ourselves. 

👀But it will get easier with practice, I promise!

message_title_3.eng: I can’t think of anything to praise my child.

message_text_3.eng:
🔔Start small! You don’t have to select anything big to praise. 

💡Find a simple behaviour that your child does that you are happy about and tell them. Even something that they already do. 

♥️ It will make a difference!

rows.title: Talking about feelings

introduction.eng:
It is completely normal for parents to have difficulty talking about and expressing emotions and feelings. Parents may be trying to recognise their emotions and communicate about them for the first time here. With practice it will become easier and more comfortable.

Here are some common challenges and possible solutions for talking about feelings. 

You can share the following messages as responses during your chat session when parents share challenges with this topic.

message_title_1.eng: My child did not want to share their emotions.

message_text_1.eng:
💚I understand that sharing feelings is challenging when it’s new. 

🌱Be patient and keep providing them with the opportunity to start sharing. 

☀️Be a model for your boys, girls, and teens by sharing your own feelings.

message_title_2.eng: I felt uncomfortable talking about my own feelings

message_text_2.eng:
⭐It's okay to feel uncomfortable talking about your own feelings. 

👀A simple way to start is by using 'I feel...' 

🌷For example, you could say, "I feel happy when we spend time together." Starting small like this can make it easier.

message_title_3.eng: Others in the household don’t think it’s a good idea to talk about emotions.

message_text_3.eng:
🔔You can try talking to them about why it might be a good idea. 

💡Encourage them to try it first. Sometimes, just giving it a try can help everyone understand each other better.

message_title_4.eng: Others in the household don’t think it’s a good idea to talk about negative emotions.

message_text_4.eng:
🔔Maybe you can have a chat with them about why it could be a good idea. 

💡Encourage them to give it a try! Talking openly about feelings can help everyone understand each other better.

message_title_5.eng: I don’t know how to name some of the feelings I am experiencing.

message_text_5.eng:
✨Naming feelings can be tough. 

🔄Try combining words you know, like happy or sad, and think about where you feel it in your body. 

🔴For example, if your chest feels tight, it might be stress. 

🔶It's okay not to have all the words – describe it the best you can.

rows.title: Setting routines

introduction.eng:
Establishing routines can be difficult for parents at first. 

Parents may also not feel comfortable involving their girls, boys, or teens in establishing a routine. You can remind them that this will make it more likely that their child will follow the rule and will also help their child learn responsibilities.

Here are some common challenges and possible solutions for setting routines for one-on-one time and other activities: 

You can share the following messages as responses to the challenges:

message_title_1.eng: Parents should be the one setting the rule, not the child.

message_text_1.eng:
When we establish rules together with our
children, that helps the family to understand each other better.

 The rules will be more realistic and children will be more willing and able to follow the rules.

message_title_2.eng: We made the routine, but my child does not follow it.

message_text_2.eng:
I get that it's challenging when your child isn't following the routine you set. 😔

Think about your routine – is it fair and realistic? What can your child actually do? Adjust the routine if necessary. 

Praise your child when they do follow the routine.

message_title_3.eng: When we tried to set a routine, we got into an argument

message_text_3.eng: When did you set the routine? Was the child calm? How did you approach it? If you or your girls, boys, or teens are hungry or tired, it is better to talk about the routines at a later point.

message_title_4.eng: We were not able to stick to the routine

message_text_4.eng: Make sure you have a routine that can be kept easily. For example, try having one meal together every week instead of every night.

rows.title: Supporting child’s learning

introduction.eng:
Here are some common challenges and possible solutions for supporting caregivers to help their child’s learning. 

You can share the following messages as responses during your weekly chat when parents share challenges with this topic.

message_title_1.eng: My girl or boy does not want to learn.

message_text_1.eng:
💡Try to understand why girl or boy doesn't want to learn. It could be due to frustration, lack of motivation, unidentified learning difficulties, or simply disinterest in the teaching method.

🎵Adapt the activities to what girl or boy enjoys. For example, if they enjoy music, consider songs about numbers and words. Make it fun! 

🎨Let girl or boy choose what they want to learn. Celebrate their achievements, no matter how small. This will help girl or boy feel confident and be independent. 

💙 Model the behaviour. When a girl or boy will see you be enthusiastic about learning, they will want to learn too! 

📱 For playful, educational ideas, type @global.trigger_play at any time!

message_title_2.eng: I don't know what to do with my teen.

message_text_2.eng:
📝 You could make a weekly plan with your teen for after school and weekends. 

🌙 Include activities for learning, relaxing, and fun so that it is enjoyable for your teen. Come up with these ideas together!
 
🎉 Helping your teen have more routine is a great way to support their learning!

message_text_3.eng:
💙 I’m sorry you’re feeling overwhelmed. 

💡 Try doing short, simple, and fun things that can fit in with your routine. 

🌈 For example, point at things like letters, numbers, colours, and objects and tell girl or boy what they are. Start slowly and simply.

For older teen, 🔄contact your teen's teacher or school to ask for some advice. 

🍚 If you’re busy, just involve your child in what you are doing.

rows.title: Helping your child give structure

introduction.eng:
Here are some common challenges and possible solutions that parents may experience when giving their girls, boys, or teens structure. 

You can share the following messages as responses during your weekly chat when parents share challenges with this topic.

message_title_1.eng: My girl or boy could not agree on one specific rule or routine.

message_text_1.eng:
📖 When creating rules, it is important to think about the age of each girl or boy so you can come up with routines that are fair for their age.

⏰ This is most important for bedtime, the time to come home, and household chores.

💡 Try to agree on a small and meaningful incentive that can motivate girl or boy to follow the rule. Consider options like playing a 15-minute board game with the family, choosing the food for the day, or enjoying a 30-minute trip to the park. 

What other ideas come to mind?

message_title_2.eng: My teen felt it was unfair that they have to follow the rule while I don’t have to follow it.

message_text_2.eng:
⭐ Our teens learn best from us.

✅ The more we follow the rules, the more they will follow the rules too. 

🌈 You can adapt the rule to make sure that it is something everyone can follow.

message_title_3.eng: My girl or boy felt it was unfair that they had to follow the rule while I didn’t have to follow it.

message_text_3.eng:
⭐ Our girls and boys learn best from us.

✅ The more we follow the rules, the more they will follow the rules too.

💛 You can adapt the rule to make sure that it is something everyone can follow.

message_title_4.eng: My teen is finding it challenging to adapt to a new routine or structure.

message_text_4.eng:
⏰ Adjusting to a new routine can be tough for both teens and us adults, too! Remember, it takes time.

🔑 Introduce the new routine gradually, starting with small changes and building on what’s familiar. Give them cues to signal upcoming transitions. 

🌷 If you are concerned about your teen’s ability to adapt, type @global.trigger_grow to take the developmental assessment and explore if there is a need for additional support.

message_title_5.eng: I felt uncomfortable because I think an adult should create the rule, not my girl or boy.

message_text_5.eng:
🌷 When we create rules together with our girls and boys, we build trust and an open relationship with them.

🔑 The rules we set will be more realistic and girl or boy will be more willing and able to follow the rule.

💡Think about the valuable lessons you’ll be teaching girl or boy, such as working together and taking initiative.

rows.title: Supporting positive child behaviour

introduction.eng:
Here are some common challenges and possible solutions for supporting positive child behaviour. 

You can share the following messages as responses during your weekly chat when parents share challenges with this topic.

message_title_1.eng: I can’t redirect my girl or boy to a positive behaviour when they are misbehaving.

message_text_1.eng:
🌱 Next time, try to catch the misbehaviour early on, before it sets in or gets worse.

👂 Talk to them about this behaviour when both of you feel calmer.

⭐ Remember to praise your girl or boy when they behave well.

message_title_2.eng: I am too angry to find anything positive to say to my teen after they have misbehaved.

message_text_2.eng:
⏸ Next time, when you are overwhelmed or angry, take a deep breath. If needed, walk away from the situation before you react. 

Remember, your teen’s behaviour isn’t meant to hurt you. As teens, it's normal for them to explore their limits. 

Later, find something small and clear that your teen is doing and you wish they could do more of. Then, praise them when they do it.

message_title_3.eng: I get too angry at my girl or boy and find it difficult to be positive with them when they are no longer misbehaving.

message_text_3.eng:
🌱 It is normal to sometimes get angry at our girls and boys when they are misbehaving, especially when they are driving us crazy.

⏸ Next time, when you are overwhelmed or angry, take a deep breath. If needed, walk away from the situation before you react. 

Remember, your teen’s behaviour isn’t meant to hurt you. As girls and boys, it's normal for them to explore their limits. 

Later, find something small and clear that your teen is doing and you wish they could do more of. Then, praise them when they do it. 

☀️ Later, find something small and clear that your girl or boy is doing and you wish they could do more of it. Then, praise them when they do it.

message_title_4.eng: I got very angry with my teen and shouted at them.

message_text_4.eng:
⏸ First, take a pause.

💚 Be kind to yourself. You are both learning and it’s okay not to get it right all the time.

If you are feeling overwhelmed or angry, take a deep breath. If needed, walk away from the situation before you react. 

Remember, your teen’s behaviour isn’t meant to hurt you. As teens, it's normal for them to explore their limits.

🌱 When you feel calmer, you could say sorry for shouting. Even if you meant some of what you said and want them to hear that, you can say sorry for how you said it.

🎈 Repeat the core message of what you were trying to say in a calmer way.

💛Make them feel loved, even when you and your teen are facing difficult situation.

message_title_5.eng: I forgot to give my girl or boy a chance to do what I asked before giving the consequence.

message_text_5.eng:
💚 That’s okay, this is all about learning!

💡 When you give girl or boy a choice, you teach them decision-making skills.

✨ It does not always work, but when it does, it helps avoid giving them a consequence later!

💡You can try it next time. Slowly, it will become a habit.
